Create a B2B marketing strategy for a company that is Supplying the UK’s KBB and furniture industry, they are an internationally-trusted manufacturer and distributor of furniture fittings, accessories, hardware and ironmongery. From tools, fixings, handles and innovative storage solutions, to sliding door systems, lighting solutions and even rise and fall desks. They have 25,000 globally-sourced products in stock, and offer free next day delivery. 

1. Research findings
Recent research found that one in five people said they don’t like their current kitchen, with badly designed storage, limited space and poor layout cited as the top three bugbears. Among the homeowners we spoke to, 86% reported that their kitchen affects their emotional and mental health. The findings of this research provide highly valuable insight to a number of our customers, including furniture manufacturers, kitchen designers and installers.

How would you plan a content strategy using these findings to achieve the objectives of customer engagement and acquisition for these audiences. Additionally how would you co-ordinate resources to deliver this?

2. Content priorities 

What would your first 90 days at this company as a creative content manager look like? What would you prioritise in order to deliver the existing content strategy?

1. Content strategy:

Given the research findings, the content strategy would aim to educate and inspire furniture manufacturers, kitchen designers and installers on how to address the common issues of kitchen design and layout. The strategy would be a mix of educational content, inspiration galleries and product promotion, with the aim of positioning the company as a trusted partner in the industry.

To achieve customer engagement and acquisition, the content strategy would include the following elements:

* Educational blog posts and guides on how to design kitchens for optimal storage and layout
* Social media campaigns highlighting real-life examples of kitchen design and renovation
* An inspiration gallery featuring successful kitchen designs and renovations that have overcome common issues
* Email newsletters featuring product promotions, special offers and industry news
* Collaborations with influencers and industry experts to create engaging content and promote the brand

To coordinate resources, the company could allocate a content marketing budget and hire a content marketing manager to oversee the strategy. The marketing team could work closely with the product development team to ensure that all new products are showcased in the content strategy.

2. Content priorities:

In the first 90 days as a creative content manager, the priorities would be:

1. Conducting a content audit to identify existing content and its effectiveness
2. Creating a content calendar that aligns with the company’s marketing objectives and seasonal trends
3. Developing a content plan that includes blog posts, social media campaigns, email newsletters and influencer collaborations
4. Identifying key influencers and industry experts to collaborate with
5. Creating a content style guide to ensure consistency across all channels
6. Developing a reporting framework to measure the effectiveness of the content strategy
7. Coordinating with the product development team to ensure that new products are showcased in the content strategy.

By focusing on these priorities, the company can establish a strong content marketing foundation that will drive engagement and acquisition among their target audience.
What would "developing a reporting framework to measure the effectiveness of the content strategy" entail? can you break down how to do this effectively

Developing a reporting framework to measure the effectiveness of the content strategy involves setting up metrics and tools to track and analyze the performance of the content across different channels. This framework helps you to monitor progress towards your marketing objectives, and make data-driven decisions to optimize your content strategy.

To develop an effective reporting framework, here are some key steps:

1. Define your marketing objectives: Identify the key metrics that are aligned with your business goals. These could include website traffic, engagement rate, conversion rate, sales, customer acquisition cost, or customer lifetime value.
2. Identify the metrics to track: Based on your marketing objectives, determine the key performance indicators (KPIs) that you will track to measure the effectiveness of your content. For example, if your objective is to increase website traffic, then you would track metrics such as page views, bounce rate, time on site, and referral sources.
3. Choose the tools to use: Select the tools that you will use to track and analyze the data. Some examples include Google Analytics, social media analytics tools, email marketing software, and influencer tracking tools.
4. Set up tracking and reporting: Configure the tools to track the metrics you identified, and set up regular reporting to monitor progress towards your marketing objectives. Ensure that the reports are easy to understand and accessible to all stakeholders.
5. Analyze the data and optimize the strategy: Use the data to identify what is working and what isn't, and make data-driven decisions to optimize the content strategy. For example, if you notice that a particular type of content is driving more traffic to your website, then you may decide to create more of that content.

By developing a reporting framework, you will be able to measure the effectiveness of your content marketing strategy and make data-driven decisions to optimize it for better results.
what metrics would could best be used to track customer engagement and acquisition

To track customer engagement and acquisition, you can use a combination of metrics that reflect different aspects of your content marketing strategy. Here are some key metrics that could be used:

1. Website traffic: This measures the number of people who visit your website from different channels such as social media, search engines, email, and other sources. This metric can indicate the effectiveness of your content in driving traffic to your website.
2. Time on site: This measures the amount of time that visitors spend on your website. This metric can indicate the level of engagement and interest in your content.
3. Bounce rate: This measures the percentage of visitors who leave your website after viewing only one page. A high bounce rate may indicate that visitors are not finding the content engaging or relevant.
4. Conversion rate: This measures the percentage of visitors who take a desired action on your website, such as making a purchase, filling out a form, or subscribing to a newsletter. This metric can indicate the effectiveness of your content in driving conversions and customer acquisition.
5. Social media engagement: This measures the number of likes, comments, shares, and other interactions on your social media posts. This metric can indicate the level of engagement and interest in your content on social media.
6. Email open and click-through rates: This measures the percentage of recipients who open and click on links in your email campaigns. This metric can indicate the effectiveness of your content in engaging and retaining email subscribers.

By tracking these metrics, you can gain insights into how your content is engaging and acquiring customers, and use that information to optimize your content marketing strategy for better results.
